rows: A small, seed-like, indehiscent dry fruit
An adjective describing radially-symmetric flowers; i.e., flowers with more than one plane of symmetry
Clusters of several to many individual berries, follicles, or samaras derived from multiple separate pistils of a single flower
A leaf arrangement in which leaves are arranged singly, one leaf per nod, alternating on either side of the stem
The length of twig between two sets of bud scale scars, or between the terminal bud and a set of bud scale scars
The pollen-producing part of the stamen
Appendages (e.g. leaves and bracts) are produced along axes, and grow to a fixed size and shape, in characteristic patterns of arrangement
An adjective describing a structure which lies flat (e.g hairs)
A fleshy, usually colourful outgrowth of a seed stalk that (at least partially) surrounds the seed and contributes to attractiveness for animal dispersal
Axes are the trunks of trees, individual stems, branches, or twigs, all of which typically continue to grow in length from a bud at the tip
The position in the angle formed between the stem and the upper side of the leaf stalk
Buds found in the axil of a leaf
A fleshy, one- to many-seeded fruit derived from one or many carpels, with divisions that equal the number of carpels
A compound leaf which is twice pinnate; i.e., leaflets are arranged along rachillae, which are themselves arranged along the rachis
Flowers containing both male and female reproductive organs. Bisexual plants are neither monoecious nor dioecious
A whitish powdery deposit or coating, as on the surface of certain fruits and leaves
A modified or specialized leaf associated with a reproductive structure such as a flower, inflorescence, or cone scale
An adjective describing plants having bracts
Small bracts associated with individual flowers in a cluster
An adjective describing a plant with wide, flat leaves. There are two types of broad leaves: simple and compound
Scale-like modified leaves that protect the lateral and terminal buds
Scars surrounding the twig, which are left by the previous year's terminal bud
Smaller markings within a leaf scar left by vascular bundle connections between the leaf and the twig
The collective name for the sepals, which may all be free from one another or form a tube
A dehiscent dry fruit derived from a compound ovary that opens along one or more sutures
A single, ovule-bearing unit, sometimes having individual ovaries and sometimes connecting to a shared basal ovary
A type of broad leaf divided into separate blades called leaflets
The collective name for the petals, which may all be free from one another or form a tube
A type of flower cluster in which the lower stalks are proportionally longer so that the flowers form a flat or slightly convex head
The upper leafy portion of a tree
Fruits which split open to release their seeds
A sexual system in seed plants where distinct unisexual individuals produce either male or female gametes
A fleshy or leathery fruit in which the innermost layer of the ovary wall is hardened into a stone or stones
Fruits which have a hard, dry pericarp around their seeds, where the exocarp, mesocarp, and endocarp aren't clearly distinguishable
An adjective describing plants lacking bracts
The innermost layer of the pericarp which surrounds a seed in a fruit
The outer layer of the pericarp of a fruit
The pairs of leaves on the upper and lower surfaces in a flattened foliage spray
Fruits with a fleshy pericarp around their seeds
The floral configuration where a structure surrounds the ovary, and the other floral parts (sepals, petals, stamens) are attached to the rim of the floral cup
A modified shoot often arising from axils, consisting of an axis that bears specialized appendages (e.g. sepals, petals, stamens, and pistils)
A fern-like growth of 2-ranked branchlets composed of pairs of overlapping scale leaves. When foliage is in flattened sprays, the scale leaves are arranged in overlapping pairs on 4 sides
An elongate dry fruit derived from a single simple ovary that opens on one side
The seed-bearing structure in angiosperms that is formed from the ovary after flowering
Structures that produce oily or sugary secretions
An adjective meaning to be covered with a greyish, bluish, or whitish waxy coating or bloom that is easily rubbed off
Small outgrowths of the epidermis, found on leaves, stems, and branches. Hairs are usually long and narrow, and can be straight, branched, or gland-tipped
Dry fruits which do not split open
The floral configuration where the ovary sits below the other floral parts (sepals, petals, and stamens), which are attached at the tip of the ovary
A cluster that bears many individual flowers on, or branching from, one or more common stalks
The structure formed by whorls of bracts beneath a flower cluster
An adjective describing leaves that have a distinct, sharp angled edge fold along the midrib or in the bottom, resembling the keel of a boat
The leaf blade tissue, excluding vascular tissue
The pairs of leaves at right angles on either side of the facial pair in a flattened foliage spray
Leaf veins which branch from the midrib
A flattened structure which serves as the main organ of photosynthesis and transpiration. All leaves have an axillary bud
The mark on a twig left by the shedding of a leaf, indicating where the previous year's leaf stalk was attached
The smaller blades making up a compound leaf. There are no buds at the base of a leaflet.
The characteristic flattened two-parted dehiscent dry fruit of the legume family which splits open at sutures along both edges
One of many raised pores in the stem of a woody plant that enable gas exchange between the atmosphere and the twig
A chamber within an ovary, anther, sporangium, or fruit. In ovaries and fruit, each locule usually corresponds to a carpel
Main shoots that elongate between the nodes, becoming branches and trunks that contribute to the woody framework of a tree
The middle layer of the pericarp of a fruit, between the endocarp and the exocarp
The primary, middle vein in a leaf
A sexual system in seed plants where separate male and female cones or flowers are present on the same plant
Clusters of many individual, small, dry or fleshy fruits, each from a separate flower and often in ball-like heads
Glands that secrete sugary liquids to attract insect pollinators; often found at the base of the stamens or on the inner rim of the floral cup
A narrow, pointed leaf that may be borne in bundles or singly. Bundles are inserted above a non-photosynthetic scale leaf
The position of the needle relative to the branch. Needles may be curved or straight. They may lie in a flat plane, be angled upward, or project at right angles to the stem
Leaves that form on long shoots during the growing season
The site of leaf attachment, an axillary bud, and potentially a lateral branch
A fairly large, dry, indehiscent fruit with a thick, bony ovary wall surrounding a single seed
A cup-like sheath surrounding or enclosing some nuts, formed from involucral bracts
An outer shell in some nuts formed from involucral bracts
A leaf arrangement in which leaves are arranged in pairs, opposite to one another at the same node
The part of the pistil which holds the ovules. There are three possible positions of the ovary relative to other floral parts
The structure that gives rise to and contains the female reproductive cells, and which develops into seeds
A type of compound leaf in which the leaflets all join in the same place at the leaf stalk
A type of leaf venation where the lateral veins all originate from the base of the leaf blade
A type of flower cluster in which branched groups of flowers are arranged along the primary axis; i.e., a branched raceme
The collective name for the calyx and corolla, the non-reproductive parts of the flower
The part of the fruit formed from the wall of the ripened ovary
The modified leaves that form an inner whorl surrounding the reproductive parts of flowers
An adjective describing undifferentiated tepals when they resemble petals
The leaf stalk, containing vascular bundles that transport water and mineral nutrients
The process of using sunlight to combine carbon dioxide and water to produce sugars and release oxygen
A type of compound leaf in which leaflets are arranged along a central stalk called the rachis
A type of leaf venation where the lateral veins are arranged along the midvein
The female organs of the flower, each comprised of one or more laterally joined carpels with a single ovary
A core of tissue inside the twig that is usually solid and continuous, but can be chambered, sectioned, or spongy
The male, pollen-producing reproductive structure in conifers
A fleshy fruit from an inferior ovary of (usually) two to five carpels in which the innermost layer of the ovary wall is membranous in texture
Leaves formed within a bud from the previous season
Sharp outgrowths or projections from the epidermis of a plant structure
A type of flower cluster in which stalked flowers are arranged along the primary axis
The branches of the rachis in twice or more pinnate leaves
An extension of the petiole which serves as the central stalk of a pinnate compound leaf.
A dry, indehiscent, winged fruit or fruit segment containing a single seed and adapted for wind dispersal, composed of a membranous wing and a seeded portion
Small outgrowths of the epidermis, found on leaves, stems, and branches. Scales are flattened and broad,, often with a textured or flaky surface
Leaves with little or no expanded blade portion. Scales may have a gland or be keeled on the outer face
The female, seed-producing reproductive structure in conifers. Seed cones have a central axis covered with bracts nestling seed scales
Single or multiple structures axillary to a bract, protecting a seed
The modified leaves (usually green) which typically function as protection for the flower in bud and support for the petals when in bloom
An adjective describing leaves or leaflets lacking stalks
A type of broad leaf having a single continuous blade that is not divided. It may be smooth-edged, toothed, or lobed
A type of flower cluster in which stalkless flowers are arranged along the primary axis
A leaf arrangement in which leaves rotate around the stem, not in the same plane
Shoots that grow from year to year with little internodal elongation between the annual batches of closely spaced leaves
Non-functional stamens; i.e., ones which do not produce viable pollen. Staminodes may resemble stamens or be reduced to stubs
A needle base modified into a woody peg
A sticky surface of the pistil where pollen is captured. Each branch of the stigma corresponds to a carpel
A small leaf-like appendage to a leaf, typically borne in pairs at the base of the leaf stalk. Stipules usually fall off before the rest of the leaf, often leaving distinct scars
The mark left by the stipule attached to the previous year's growth
Lines of stomates arranged on either side of the midrib that appear as yellow or white stripes on the underside or upper surface of the needle
The breathing pores in the epidermis of all leaves that are used to exchange gases and reduce water loss
A hard body found in certain fruits, produced by ossification of the endocarp or lining of the fruit
The part of the pistil which connects the stigma and the ovary
The floral configuration where the ovary sits above the other floral parts (sepals, petals, and stamens), which are attached at the base of the ovary
The collective name for the petals and sepals when they are difficult to distinguish
The bud enclosing the growing point of a shoot and its side branches
Short shoots that have been modified to have a hard, sharp point, and which may be simple or compound
The main stem of a tree, which supports the branches and connects to the roots underground - the main axis from which subsidiary branches arise
A type of flower cluster in which stalked flowers all originate from the same location and form an umbrella-like top
Flowers containing either exclusively male or exclusively female reproductive organs
A leaf arrangement in which each node bears three or more leaves
An adjective describing a bilaterally symmetrical flower; i.e., a flower with a single plane of symmetry
